body:
We would like to avoid `containsOnlyElementsOf` assertions because they can be misleading for some users (e.g., see #1075 and #1513).

What about `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes`?

A not so nice solution with existing assertons would be:

```java
List<Object> list = Arrays.asList("asd", 3, Duration.ofDays(1));
Class[] types = new Class[] { String.class, Integer.class, Duration.class }; // raw types

assertThat(list).extracting(Object::getClass)
                .containsExactly(types); // unchecked
```

but it would trigger raw types and unchecked assignment warnings.
`containsExactlyElementsOfTypes` sounds good to me. Can I implement it?
Due to the limitations of using extracting, I'm fine with `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes`, @maciejwalkowiak  thanks for contributing it.
@maciejjaskowski are you still interested in contributing this one?

Hi@joel-costigliola,
 Is this still open for contribution? I'd like to implement the `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes`.
It is @RGalways17 thanks! Let us know if you need some guidance.

@joel-costigliola I've noticed the `containsExactlyElementsOf` and `containsExactly`. How about having a similar implementation: a `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes` calling `containsExactlyTypes(toArray(iterable))` and let `containsExactlyTypes` be like `assertThat(credentialsProviders).containsExactlyTypes(AWSStaticCredentialsProvider.class, EC2ContainerCredentialsProviderWrapper.class, ProfileCredentialsProvider.class);` . 
Also, I think the assertion can be made similar to  `assertContainsExactly`, just extract a List<Object>with `getClass` to store the types and `diff` can be used(if I'm not mistaken about how it works). Then the rest part can be the similar to `assertContainsExactly`, only modifying the failure information.

@RGalways17 I think we only want to add `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes(Class... expectedTypes)`  but not overload it with `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes(List<Class<?>> expectedTypes)`, is that what you had in mind @scordio?

> Also, I think the assertion can be made similar to assertContainsExactly, just extract a Listwith getClass to store the types and diff can be used(if I'm not mistaken about how it works). Then the rest part can be the similar to assertContainsExactly, only modifying the failure information.

I agree! 
Ideally the error message should indicate that we are checking the elements types but we can start using the generic `ShouldContainExactly` error message factory to get a feel of the error message and change it if we find it could be better.

> @RGalways17 I think we only want to add `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes(Class... expectedTypes)` but not overload it with `containsExactlyElementsOfTypes(List<Class<?>> expectedTypes)`, is that what you had in mind @scordio?

Yes, that is what I had in mind, but looking again at `ObjectEnumerableAssert` I'm wondering if it makes more sense to stay closer to the existing assertions like `hasAtLeastOneElementOfType`, `hasOnlyElementsOfType`, `hasOnlyElementsOfTypes` and `doesNotHaveAnyElementsOfTypes`.

What about `hasExactlyElementsOfTypes(Class<?>... types)`?
Yes, good point let's do `hasExactlyElementsOfTypes(Class<?>... types)`, I think the naming is better
